history.content: I can't say what's better for optimizing for acceptance to grad school. However, as someone that has been in your shoes (did multiple ML SWE internships at some of the classic big tech companies (NLP in one of them)), I reflect back and can confidently say that internships were an invaluable experience and I learned things that I will not learn in any classes at Berkeley. You'll likely learn the areas of AI that are being heavily funded and what areas are not. You'll probably also learn to what extent NLP has been implemented and how the platforms are built to support the massive infrastructure for AI at your company. It also made me realize that I don't want to go to grad school for the time being. It definitely will be a good experience for you too :) Hope that helps.

children.subject: Thanks for your response, this is very helpful. I will apply to PhD to start PhD in Fall 2022. When you say apply in the Fall 2022 cycle, do you mean applying for PhD during Fall 2022 (to start in Fall 2023), or applying to PhD to start in Fall 2022?

If you currently have a research position, I'd incline towards recommending you to take the internship and continue the research while you are interning. Like the student answer said, internships are quite a valuable experience and gives you a greater sense of clarity as to whether you want to continue pursuing academia or directly enter industry after undergrad.

There are a few caveats:

- If you are applying to a masters, take the internship

- If you are applying to a PhD, but in the Fall 2022 cycle or after, take the internship

- If you are applying to a PhD this Fall, then its not that bad of an idea to take a research internship/REU. This entirely depends on your personal situation with letters of recommendation, especially if you are applying to CS. If you have 3 strong letters of recommendation, of which at least 2 are more than just "Student X did well in my class" you can probably go to the internship safely. Otherwise I'd consider an REU since CS admissions for PhD are to the point where having a rec letter that amounts to doing well in a class is generally useless (of course there are exceptions).

Just my two cents.
